description: From Middle English, from Old English, from Late Latin manna, from Ancient Greek μάννα (mánna), from Hebrew מן‎ (mān, “'manna”).

entries.meaning: (biblical) Food miraculously produced for the Israelites in the desert in the book of Exodus.
examples: And when the dew that lay was gone up, behold, upon the face of the wilderness there lay a small round thing, as small as the hoar frost on the ground. And when the children of Israel saw it, they said one to another, It is manna: for they wist not what it was. And Moses said unto them, This is the bread which the LORD hath given you to eat.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Any boon which comes into one's hands by good luck.
examples: Fair ladies, you drop manna in the way / Of starved people.

entries.meaning: The sugary sap of the manna gum tree which oozes out from holes drilled by insects and falls to the ground around the tree.[2]
examples: The icing on the cake was made from manna, which was gathered under the manna gums. Manna mixed with milk made a splendid icing.
